security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill containing educational content about clean code principles for .NET. No executable code, network calls, file operations, or system access detected. Purely educational content with code examples.

content.user_title: Apply Clean Code Principles to .NET Projects
content.value_statement: Struggling with messy, hard-to-maintain .NET code? This skill provides practical examples of DRY, KISS, and YAGNI principles to help you write cleaner, more maintainable code.
actual_capabilities: Explains DRY principle with C# code examples
Demonstrates KISS principle through refactoring examples
Shows YAGNI principle with practical scenarios
Provides clean code checklist for .NET developers
Includes naming conventions and best practices
Contains async/await patterns and error handling examples
limitations: Does not execute code or perform actual refactoring
No interactive features or code analysis

use_cases.title: Learn Clean Code Fundamentals
use_cases.description: Understand DRY, KISS, and YAGNI principles through practical C# examples and improve code quality.

use_cases.title: Guide Team Code Reviews
use_cases.description: Use as reference material during code reviews to explain clean code principles to team members.

use_cases.title: Establish Coding Standards
use_cases.description: Reference for creating team coding standards and best practices documentation.

prompt_templates.title: Review Code for DRY Violations
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this C# code and identify DRY principle violations. Suggest refactoring to eliminate duplication: [paste code]

prompt_templates.title: Simplify Complex Code
prompt_templates.prompt: This code seems over-engineered. Apply KISS principle to suggest a simpler implementation: [paste code]

prompt_templates.title: Check for YAGNI Violations
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze this code for YAGNI violations. Identify features or abstractions that aren't currently needed: [paste code]

prompt_templates.title: Complete Clean Code Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Perform a complete clean code review of this .NET code, checking against DRY, KISS, YAGNI, naming conventions, and the clean code checklist.

output_examples.input: Review this method for clean code principles: public decimal Calc(decimal a, decimal b, bool flag) { if(flag) return a*b*0.1m; else return a*b; }
output: KISS: Method name 'Calc' is unclear - should describe what it calculates
Naming: Parameter 'flag' is not descriptive - use names like 'applyDiscount'
YAGNI: Simple calculation doesn't violate YAGNI

best_practices: Use specific, descriptive names for all variables, methods, and classes
Keep methods small and focused on a single responsibility
Apply the Rule of Three before extracting common code
anti_patterns: Don't abstract code until you have at least three similar implementations
Avoid premature optimization without measuring performance first
Don't create interfaces for single implementations without future plans

faq.question: Is this skill compatible with all .NET versions?
faq.answer: Examples use modern C# features but principles apply to all .NET versions. Adjust syntax as needed for older versions.

faq.question: Can this skill analyze my actual code files?
faq.answer: No, this is educational content only. You'll need to manually apply principles to your code.

faq.question: How do I integrate this with my development workflow?
faq.answer: Use as reference during code reviews, pair programming, or when establishing team coding standards.

faq.question: Is my code sent to external services?
faq.answer: No, this skill processes everything locally. No code is transmitted or stored externally.

faq.question: What if my team uses different conventions?
faq.answer: Principles are universal. Adapt examples to match your team's specific conventions and standards.

faq.question: How does this compare to automated code analysis tools?
faq.answer: This provides educational context and reasoning. Use alongside tools like SonarQube for comprehensive code quality.
